code:
if a in b:
    print "a is in b"

text: If you also want to ignore capitals:

code:
if a.lower() in b.lower():
    print "a is in b"

if a in b:
    # ...found it, do stuff...

text: The former is probably more pythonic, but the latter lets you catch issues sooner if a or b are not the types you were expecting, since if a or b aren't strings, the latter will always fail non-silently, whereas the former can misbehave silently in some cases (for instance, 'foo' in ['foobar'] or even 'foo' in [1,2,3]).

code:
if a in b:
    # insert code here

text: Strings are treated like lists of characters in Python.
Therefore, the following will work whether a is a character and b is a string or if a is an element type and b is a list:
(Internally, Python handles strings and lists differently, but you can treat them as the same thing in many operations, like list comprehensions).
For finding one string in another, you may want to try the string find method.

code:
if b.find(a) != -1:  # -1 will be returned when a is not in b
    do_whatever

>>> a = '1324'
>>> b = '58132458495'
>>> if a in b:
      print(True)

>>> True
